subject: Dear Sir,
body:
Dear Sir,
I am writing to inform you that the president has given the final directive to the governor of the CBN, and in line with the president's directive, the DEBT APPROPRIATION MANAGEMENT was established for the process.
I noticed that your payment was included in the recently released government official gazette regarding the payment of the debt.
I believe you have seen or read the gazette of the payment in the newspapers published a week ago. They even published the names of the beneficiaries who are to benefit from the payment from the established agency, and your name was among those mentioned. It is for this reason that I am contacting you so that you can expedite the action to have your debt fund paid to you.
My name is Mr. Wilson Ogunleye, and I work at the Central Bank of Nigeria. I was drafted to the Debt Appropriation Management as the Apex bank representative, and I have been the one against the release of your fund so through in the past.
Please do not consider me as someone who is wicked, as I have nothing against you. My frustration is directed towards your so -called partner who deviated from our initial agreement when he requested that I assist in placing your payment in the computer system for processing payments to beneficiaries, which I did. However, after seeing that it was done, he absconded and did not keep to the agreement, which is why I stopped your payment.
I will not go into detail about what transpired between your so -called partner and me, as it would take up much of our time. I would prefer to deal with you directly rather than this person you call your partner.
Before we can proceed, I would like you to promise me the following and hope that you will not deviate from this, as your partner did in the past:
1. Keep your so -called partner out of this, as I do not want him to know my involvement until the fund is received by you.
2. Be willing to offer me 20% of the fund if you receive it in your account.
3. When the fund is received in your account, assist me in coming over to meet you by providing me with a letter of invitation.
4. Help me open an account in one of the preferred banks in your location where I can lodge my share and possibly assist me in deciding on a business in which to invest. I would prefer not to receive my share here due to potential inquiries by the authorities regarding the source.
5. Other matters will be discussed when we meet face to face in your country.
I await your prompt response, and once I receive it, I will inform you of how to get your payment without any upfront payment.
Please send your reply to this email: 
ogunleyewilson6@gmail.com
 Respectfully Yours,
Mr. Wilson Ogunleye

subject: Re:   Dear Sir,
body:
Hello Mr. Wilson Ogunleye,

Thank you for reaching out to me and providing such detailed information about the situation. I must say, it's quite surprising to hear that my name was mentioned in a government official gazette regarding a debt payment. I don't recall having any outstanding debts, but perhaps there's been some confusion.

I'm sorry to hear about your past experiences with my so-called partner. It sounds like a difficult situation indeed. However, I must admit that I'm not aware of any partner or agreement you're referring to.

As for your requests, they seem quite significant and I would need more time to consider them. Could you please provide more details about this debt fund? How much is it exactly? And why has it been held up until now?

Also, could you clarify what you mean by offering you a percentage of the fund? Is this a common practice in these situations?

Lastly, regarding opening an account in one of the preferred banks at my location and assisting you with business investments - could you explain why this is necessary? 

Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Dear Sir,

Thank you for your prompt response to my email.

I have been eagerly anticipating the opportunity to communicate with you
directly, rather than through the individual I previously believed to be
your partner, a claim which you have now denied. Regardless of whether or
not this individual was your partner, I am confident that we can have a
successful and fruitful transaction. I believe that fate has brought us
this opportunity, and I trust that you will handle our affiliation with
sincerity and trust, ensuring that the funds are released to your account.

I appreciate your acceptance of the conditions I outlined in my previous
email, particularly with regard to keeping this matter confidential from
your partner, as any involvement on his part could lead to serious
consequences under the civil code of conduct.

As I mentioned in my previous email, I am a member of the Debt
Appropriation Management and am responsible for the file documentation of
pending payments of debts. The contractor who executed the project in the
Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC has passed away, and I have
reason to believe that you are the next of kin to whom the payment of his
debt is owed. The agency responsible for handling these debts is the Debt
Appropriation Management (DAM).

The DAM was established to address the mishandling of funds by government
officials, which had made the process of debt payment difficult for
beneficiaries.

Under the guidelines of the DAM, the agency takes on the legal
responsibilities of the ministries processing the debts owed to each
beneficiary, recommending and releasing funds without demanding fees
payable to the ministry.

This was done to ensure accountability and to prevent the exploitation of
recipients through the imposition of various fees and charges. The DAM has
already begun
communicating with beneficiaries whose files have been handed over for the
ongoing debt reparation by the president. Your file is among those being
processed, and you will be contacted by the DAM in due course. When you
receive their message, please inform me so that I can provide guidance on
how to proceed. I am a
representative of the Central Bank of Nigeria and am part of the DAM.

I hope you understand why I cannot be directly involved in fronting your
payment to the DAM, as it would raise questions among other members of the
agency.

Therefore, we will wait for the DAM to communicate with you regarding the
payment. If you do not receive any correspondence from the DAM, I will
investigate the matter.

Please keep an eye on your inbox for any messages from the Debt
Appropriation Management, and inform me when you receive one.
The sum which is to be processed paying to you as the next of kin is
US$10,500,000.00.

Please fill the form I attached on this mail with your required information
where Dam will process the payment to you.

I look forward to hearing from you.
Sincerely,
Mr. Wilson Ogunleye

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Dear Mr. Wilson Ogunleye,

Thank you for your detailed explanation. I must admit, it's a lot to take in and I'm not entirely sure I understand everything. However, I am eager to help in any way that I can.

I find it quite surprising that the contractor who executed the project in the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation has passed away and left me as his next of kin. Could you please tell me more about this individual? How did he come to name me as his next of kin?

Also, could you explain a bit more about how the Debt Management Office works? It sounds like they have an important role in ensuring funds are distributed correctly.

Lastly, you mentioned a form attached to your email for me to fill out with my required details. Unfortunately, I didn't see any attachment with your email. Could you please resend it?

Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Dear Laurel,

I have looked into your concerns about the payment related to the past
inquiries.

After some investigation, I discovered that the person you thought was
working for you, Mrs. Obinaju, was actually representing the late
contractor. She passed away about two years ago and had been living abroad
for most of her life before returning to Nigeria to handle the late
contractor's affairs. It seems that she may have designated you as the next
of kin before her death.

The late contractor did not leave a will, and Mrs. Obinaju, in the absence
of any specified next of kin, put your name forward to receive the funds
owed for the project. This is why your email contact was included in the
contract document released to DAM, as it was believed that you might be
related to the late contractor and entitled to receive the funds.

I propose that we work together to ensure that you receive the funds as the
rightful next of kin. I will use my position to facilitate the legal
transfer of the funds to you, and we can both benefit from this
arrangement. I will guide you on how to handle any communication from the
management to ensure a smooth process.

The amount due to the late contractor is US$10,500,000.00, which is the sum
to be paid for the executed project with the Nigerian National Petroleum
Corporation.

If you agree to proceed, please keep this matter confidential and do not
discuss it with any third party to avoid our government interference which
may land me into trouble.

DAM will contact you to initiate the claim process.
Please fill out the attached reactivation form and send it to me promptly
so that I can include it in your file.

It was reliable stated the contractor died as a result of a heart-related
condition on March 12th 2007. His heart condition leading to his death was
due to the death of all members of his family in tsunami disaster in
Sumatra, Indonesia.http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Ocean_earthquake.

I look forward to your response so that we can move forward with the claim.
Best regards,

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello there,

Thank you for your detailed message. I'm sorry to hear about the passing of Mrs. Obinaju and the late contractor. It's quite a surprise to learn that I've been designated as the next of kin.

I must admit, this is all very new to me. Could you perhaps explain how Mrs. Obinaju came to choose me as the next of kin? Also, could you provide more information on what exactly my role would be in this process?

You mentioned a form that needs to be filled out - could you clarify what kind of information is required in this form? I just want to make sure I understand everything correctly before proceeding.

Lastly, you mentioned DAM will contact me - who or what is DAM? And how will they be contacting me?

Looking forward to your response.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello,

Thank you for your detailed message. I'm sorry to hear about Mrs. Obinaju's passing and the unfortunate circumstances surrounding the late contractor's family.

I must admit, this is all quite surprising to me. I had no idea that I was designated as the next of kin or that there were funds owed to me from a project with the Nigerian National Petroleum.

You mentioned a form that needs to be filled out and sent back to you. Could you please clarify what kind of information is required in this form? Also, could you explain more about how this claim process will work?

I understand the need for discretion in this matter and assure you that I won't discuss it with any third party.

Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
To receive the funds from the DAM, you need to provide your account
information in the spaces provided. If there is any information you don't
understand, please let me know. The payment process will be a bank to bank
transfer.

Once the DAM approves the payment, a certificate of reactivation will be
issued to the beneficiary who completes the verification process. The DPVB
(Directorate of Project Verification Board) will then request the Ministry
of Finance to issue Foreign Exchange Allocation Approval, which will enable
the CBN to release the funds through an approved affiliate bank.

This process will take not more than 48 hours.

Your co-operation in complying with the President's debt reparation under
the policies in the establishment of DAM will be required from you the
beneficiary.

Thank you.

Wilson

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello Wilson,

Thank you for your detailed explanation. It sounds like a thorough process. I'm curious, could you explain more about the role of the DPVB of Project Board? And what exactly is the Foreign Exchange Allocation Approval?

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Best regards.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello Wilson,

Thank you for your detailed explanation. It sounds like a well-structured process. I'm curious, could you please explain more about the role of the Project Board and the Ministry of Finance in this process? Also, what is the significance of the Foreign Exchange Allocation Approval?

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Best regards.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
The DPVB or Directorate of Project Verification Board is responsible for
approving any debt payments authorized by the DAM to be paid to a
beneficiary.
Once DAM approves a payment, DPVB signs off on the approval and instructs
the Ministry of Finance to prepare the foreign exchange allocation to the
Central Bank for the release of funds to the beneficiary.
The Ministry of Finance then issues the Foreign Exchange Allocation
approval to the CBN to acquire the dollar exchange for the payment to a
beneficiary, in accordance with the policies of the debt reparation
stipulates.

Rest assured, I am in the DAM office and will ensure the successful release
of the funds to your account. I can understand why you are that curious but
I have told the personal attorney to the late contractor to write you and
explain to you well how we planned to achieve this.

The name of the attorney is Smith Udumakaihe Esq. He is aware of the
transaction and he was the legal representative to the Late Mr. Liu.
Initially, I have not wanted to let you know about his involvement until
you prove to me your acceptance to be fronted the next of kin because of
how confidential we expected it to be.
The legal representative to the late contractor, Smith Udumakaihe Esq.,
will provide you with more details on the process and the necessary
documents to prove your status as the next of kin to the late contractor.
He will also address any concerns you may have about the transaction.
Your co-operation is essential for us to achieve this goal for our mutual
benefit.

Thank you,
Wilson

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello Wilson,

Thank you for your detailed explanation. It's quite a complex process, isn't it? I'm trying to understand everything better. Could you please explain what the roles of the DPVB and DAM are in this process? And how does the Ministry of Finance fit into all of this?

Also, could you tell me more about Smith Udumakaihe Esq.? How long has he been working as an attorney? What is his role in this whole situation?

I'm looking forward to hearing from you.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Please check your mail, the barrister has just called to tell me he has
sent you mail.

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello there,

Thank you for your message. I appreciate the update about the barrister's email. Could you please tell me more about what the email contains? And also, could you kindly provide some more information about this barrister and why he is contacting me?

Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
The office rule is simple and defined: Dam needs to pay a large sum of
money, so there are offices that will be involved in the payment process.
The DPVB monitors Dam's debt approval and signs off on the final approval
of the payment after reviewing all the claim documents. They then instruct
the Ministry of Finance to approve the allocation of the amount to be
released to the CBN for onward release to the beneficiary's account.
The Ministry of Finance is the government department responsible for
financial matters as in your country.

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Like I stated in my previous mail to you. The barrister was the one who
worked with the late contractor. He was the legal representative to the man
here when the man was alive. He worked with him during the time the
contract was awarded and executed by the late contractor.
I think he will be in the right position to give you more details about
this project and payment in Dam.

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello,

Thank you for your response and the information provided. It's interesting to know about the barrister's involvement with the late man and his role during the contract period. 

Could you please share more details about this project? What was its nature and what role did the late man play in it? Also, could you elaborate on what you mean by 'payment in Dam'? I'm not quite familiar with this term.

Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best regards.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello there,

Thank you for sharing this information with me. It's quite interesting to learn about the process involved in the payment approval. I must admit, it's a bit complex for me to understand fully.

Could you please explain a bit more about what DPVB stands for and their role in this process? Also, how does the Ministry of Finance interact with the CBN during this process?

I'm really curious to know more about these procedures. Thanks again for your time!

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
I apologize for the delay in responding to your email. I left the office
early yesterday to see my doctor as I was feeling feverish. I am feeling
better now.

Regarding your query, the DPVB is an associated office of the government
responsible for approving beneficiaries' debts for release of owed funds.
Once the DAM approves the file, it is then taken to the DPVB for final
approval of the payment, and then to the Ministry of Finance, which
prepares the foreign exchange allocation for payment to the Central Bank
for further release of the funds to the beneficiary's account.

The Ministry of Finance manages federal debts, and any debts approved by
the DAM must pass through the ministry before the Central Bank pays the
debts to the recipient.

The DAM is in charge of vetting files of all claims by beneficiaries
forwarded by the President, and the process must be completed before the
funds are finally paid out. Such large sums of money cannot be approved and
paid without the involvement of this three government offices.

Wilson

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello Wilson,

Thank you for your detailed explanation. I'm glad to hear that you're feeling better now. Health is indeed wealth.

Your explanation about the process involving DPVB, DAM, and the Ministry of Finance was quite enlightening. It's interesting to learn how these government offices work together in approving and releasing funds.

I'm curious though, what does DPVB stand for? And what about DAM? Also, could you please elaborate on the role of the Central Bank in this process?

Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello Laura, I hope you're doing well. I apologize for not responding to
your emails earlier. I've been very busy with work at the office.

Those offices you have mentioned are all connected, no payment of  the debt
owed to a beneficiary can be released without going through the approval of
those offices. This is a standard practice in most countries to ensure
checks and balances.

The approval and documentation from Dam after approval in Dam are taken to
DPVB, where they conduct checks to verify the payment. Once they are
satisfied with the proof provided, they will sign off on the approval,
which then goes to the Ministry of Finance. The Ministry of Finance will
then release the Exchange allocation to the Central Bank of Nigeria, which
will carry out the release of the funds to the beneficiary's account.

The Central Bank of Nigeria, being the Apex bank, will release the funds to
the beneficiary's account as prescribed by DPVB.

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello there,

Thank you for your detailed explanation. It's fascinating to learn about the process and how all these offices are interconnected. I must admit, it's a bit complex for me to grasp fully.

Could you perhaps explain a bit more about the role of DPVB in this process? And why is the approval from Dam so crucial before it reaches DPVB?

Also, once the Ministry of Finance releases the Exchange allocation to the Central Bank of Nigeria, how long does it usually take for the funds to be released to the account?

I appreciate your patience in explaining this to me.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Dear

I feel like I've explained this to you multiple times, and I'm frustrated
that you keep asking the same question. In any organization, whether
private or government, there are different departments that handle specific
functions.
For example, in established companies, the accounting department has its
own responsibilities, and the person who approves payments is not
necessarily the same person who works in the accounting department.

This is similar to the relationship between DAM and DPVB. The DAM reviews
claims from beneficiaries and approves payments, and then the DPVB gives
the final approval. These two offices work together in the process of
reviewing and authorizing debt payments.


The DAM's approval is crucial because they scrutinize the beneficiaries and
their claim documents. They have a direct link to the ministries that
awarded the projects and sometimes visit the ministry to assess the nature
of the project and the associated documents. They serve as the link between
other offices and the president who created the office to handle debts.

Once the Central Bank receives the Allocation, it should not take more than
48 hours for the funds to be released.

Thank you for your understanding.
Sincerely,
Wilson

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello Wilson,

Thank you for your detailed explanation. I must admit, some of these processes can be quite confusing to me. So, if I understand correctly, the DAM and DPVB are two separate entities that work together in reviewing and approving debt payments?

Also, you mentioned that once the Central Bank receives the approval, it should not take more than a few hours for the funds to be released. Is this always the case or are there instances where it might take longer?

I appreciate your patience in explaining all this to me.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Exactly, DAM and DPVB are separate entities in the payment of debts. It is
the DAM that reviews the files and approves them before passing them over
to DPVB for final approval.
Regarding the Central Bank releasing the funds, it should take 48 hours,
but delays can occur, but it shouldn't exceed 72 hours.

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello there,

Thank you for sharing this information. It's interesting to learn about the roles of DAM and DPVB in the debt payment process. I'm curious, what might cause these delays in the Central Bank releasing the funds? And is there anything that can be done to expedite this process?

Looking forward to your response!

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Dear Laura,
I received your mail and the content is okay.
It is not mandatory for there to be a delay, but if it does happen, it
could be due to a technical problem within the central Bank and it is only
the bank that can rectify it.

If the receiving beneficiary complains about the delay, the DAM has the
right to question the delay with the Central Bank.

I understand your need to be cautious and ensure that you are making the
right decision. I am confident that we will succeed, and you will be
fortunate to be part of this project.

I would appreciate it if you could make your final decision today so that
we can move forward. We have been delaying this issue for too long, and DAM
is on the verge of paying some of the beneficiaries next week. If we had
acted sooner, we could have been on the list.

Please let me know your decision today, and if you choose to proceed, you
will receive more information about the process as we progress.

Thank you,
Wilson

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello Wilson,

Thank you for your prompt response and the detailed explanation. I appreciate your patience and understanding in this matter.

I'm curious about the technical problems that might occur within the Central Bank. Could you please elaborate on what kind of issues these might be? Also, how often do such delays happen?

You mentioned DAM has the right to question the delay with the Central Bank. How does this process work? Is there a specific protocol that needs to be followed?

I understand the urgency of making a decision, but I believe it's important to have all necessary information before proceeding. Could you provide more details about what being part of this project entails?

Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Dear I am done with these questions that I feel are irrelevant.
Even in banks we do have delays due to networks. Your end such technical
problems occur.
I have not told you it will happen but may happen or not.

please as we progress you will receive details on the project, we just
require your intention to stand in the part of next of kin.

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello there,

Thank you for your response. I understand that technical issues can occur anywhere, even in banks. It's quite reassuring to know that you're being upfront about potential delays.

I'm intrigued by the idea of standing as the next of kin. Could you please elaborate more on this? What exactly does it entail and what would be my responsibilities?

Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
i don't think there is much deal when you accept we present your account
and name the next of kin to the late contractor. Any question from any
offices being throne to you we will give you the proper answer to give.

my dear, the responsibility required of you is to receive the fund your
side and make sure is save, until i and possibly the barrister come over to
meet you for the disbursement. have our share invested in your country but
we can bring the money back to our country as we will be investigated about
the source of the money.

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello there,

Thank you for reaching out and explaining the situation to me. It sounds like a very interesting opportunity indeed. I'm just a bit curious about some details, if you don't mind clarifying.

Firstly, could you please explain more about the process of naming someone as the next of kin? How does that work exactly? 

Secondly, when you mention 'the fund', could you specify what kind of fund this is? Is it an inheritance or something else?

Lastly, I'm intrigued by your plan to invest in my country. Could you share more about what type of investment you're considering?

I look forward to hearing from you soon!

Best wishes,
Laura

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
the process is what the barrister intend to do by approaching the court to
get the court certification and every other thing will fellow.

As the next of kin the fund being release to you is inherited fund.
We will invest in any think that one can invest on and make proceeds. You
will know better the kind of investment that will suit us, especially may
be in real estates or in any thing you can advise us.

Please i want to know your decision if not this will be last response. your
more questions can come after we have commence on the project.
Thank you.

subject: Re: Dear Sir,
body:
Hello,

Thank you for your message. It sounds like an interesting proposition, but I have a few questions to better understand the process.

Firstly, could you please explain more about the role of the barrister in this process? What exactly does he intend to do by the court?

Secondly, I'm curious about the nature of this inherited fund. How was it acquired and why is it being released to me?

Lastly, regarding investment opportunities, real estate certainly sounds promising. However, could you provide more details on how we would proceed with such an investment? 

I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Best regards.

Best wishes,
Laura
